c:complexType.name: BarChartCommon
c:complexType.c:documentation:
The common options documentation class of the Bar family charts.
For information on the supported data formats see .

c:property.name: categoryRole
c:property.c:documentation:
The category visual role is a plot-level visual role that represents a generic logical grouping of the data points and is visually encoded by grouping bars in separate bands along the base axis.
This is a shortcut property for the main plot's .

c:property.name: valueRole
c:property.c:documentation:
The value visual role is a plot-level visual role that represents its main measure, specifically, it is visually encoded by the orthogonal height of bars.
This is a shortcut property for the main plot's .

c:property.name: baseAxis
c:property.c:documentation:
The base cartesian axis panel options.
When the chart is vertical the base axis is laid out horizontally.
See to know the additional names by which a cartesian axis can be referred to.

c:property.name: panelSizeRatio
c:property.c:documentation:
Percentage of occupied space over total space in a discrete axis band.
See for more information.

c:complexType.name: BarPlotCommon
c:complexType.c:documentation: The common options documentation class of the Bar family plots.

c:property.name: visualRoles
c:property.c:documentation:
The plot's visual roles map.
See for more information.

c:property.name: valuesAnchor
c:property.c:documentation: The alignment of a value label relative to its corresponding visual element position.

c:property.name: valuesMask
c:property.c:documentation:
The values mask used to build the text of value labels.
The mask may contain scene variable names and/or scene atom names, like in the examples:
scene variables: {category}: {value} EUR, could yield Drinks: 3.45 EUR
atom variables: {#family} - {#product}, could yield Plains - Boeing 747

c:property.name: valuesOptimizeLegibility
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if legibility of value labels should be optimized.
The current algorithm varies the text color so that it has enough contrast for the fill color of the associated bar.
It is applied only when a value label is considered to be inside its associated bar. Presently, it is considered to be inside, if the center point of the label is within the bounds of the bar.

c:property.name: valuesOverflow
c:property.c:documentation:
The behavior to apply when the text of a value label does not fit within the bounds of its associated bar.
This option applies only when is true.
Moreover, it also applies only for certain configurations of value label placement, relative to the associated bar. Presently, the supported placements are:
non-negative text margin, .
horizontal text — on horizontal or vertical bars; on vertical bars, text is allowed to overflow, without trimming. Text is horizontal when
is such that sin(textAngle) = 0 (example: 0).
vertical text on vertical bars — text is vertical when
is such that cos(textAngle) = 0 (example: Math.PI/2, -Math.PI/2, 3*Math.PI/2, ...).
text that is intensionally inside the bar — this would be too painful to enumerate; generally, it depends on the values of , , and .
When an unsupported placement occurs, the label is shown.
Note that for the purposes of hiding and trimming, the value of is used for more that the distance between the anchor points of the label and the bar.
It is also included as a required margin at the side opposite to the label's anchor. For example, if a label is anchored with a bottom textBaseline, the text margin must also be available on the top side of the label.
Also, the same margin is respected on the horizontal sides of the label (left and right), whether or not they are anchor sides.

c:property.name: barSizeRatio
c:property.c:documentation:
The percentage of the grouped bar width versus the space between grouped bars (does not apply to stacked bars).
A number between 0.05 and 1.

c:property.name: barSizeMax
c:property.c:documentation:
The maximum width of a bar, in pixel units.
A number not less than 1, possibly infinity.

c:property.name: barOrthoSizeMin
c:property.c:documentation:
The minimum height of a non-null valued bar, in pixel units.
If you want that null-valued bars also show up, as zero bars do, consider using a
.
If you do not want to show zero-valued bars, then set this option to zero.
A finite number, not less than 0.

c:property.name: maxBarSize
c:property.c:documentation: Use instead. The maximum width of a bar, in pixel units.

c:property.name: barStackedMargin
c:property.c:documentation:
The space between bars of a given stack, in pixel units (applies to stacked bars).
A non-negative number.

c:property.name: overflowMarkersVisible
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if overflow and underflow markers are shown when the bars are drawn off the plot area.
Bars can be drawn off the plot area by use of the continuous axis properties fixedMin and fixedMax.

c:property.name: valuesNormalized
c:property.c:documentation: Normalize the domain of bars' values by category.

c:property.name: extensionPoints
c:property.c:documentation: The extension points object contains style definitions for the marks of the plot.

c:complexType.name: BarPlotCommonExtensionPoints
c:complexType.c:documentation:
The extension points of the bar family plot types.
Plot extension points can be specified:
at the plot level, in the extensionPoints property, without need to prefix the extension point with the plot id or name.
at the plot options level, directly, without need to prefix the extension point with the plot id or name.
if it is an internal plot (main, plot2 or trend), at the chart options level, directly.
To use an extension point you must find its full name, by joining:
plot property name (ex: bar)
extension property (ex: panel)
the "_" character
extension sub-property (ex: strokeStyle)
and obtaining, for the examples, the camel-cased name: barPanel_strokeStyle (see ).
The extension points of the main plot of a chart may be used without the plot property name prefix. In the example, when the bar plot is the main plot, the extension point can be written as panel_strokeStyle.

c:property.name: panel
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the series panel of the bar plot.

The extension point of the bar mark.
This extension point can only be used by prefixing it with the property name of the plot.
So, supposing this plot is under a property named bar, and it is desired to access the strokeStyle property of the bar mark, the full name of the extension property would be bar_strokeStyle.

c:property.name: label
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the value label mark.

c:property.name: underflowMarker
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the underflow marker.

c:property.name: overflowMarker
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the overflow marker.

c:complexType.name: BarPlotCommonVisualRoles
c:complexType.c:documentation: The visual roles options class of the bar family plot types.

c:property.name: category
c:property.c:documentation:
The category visual role is a plot-level visual role that represents a generic logical grouping of the data points and is visually encoded by grouping bars in separate bands along the base axis.
On the bar family charts it is restricted to be discrete.
For additional information, see the base version of this property: .

c:property.name: value
c:property.c:documentation:
The value visual role is a plot-level visual role that represents its main measure, specifically, it is visually encoded by the orthogonal height of bars.
The value visual role accepts and requires one or more numeric dimensions and automatically binds to a single numeric dimension whose name has the value prefix.
When bound to more than one dimension, the special valueRole.dim discriminator dimension can be used to control the behaviour:
Bind at least one of the discrete visual roles multiChart, series or category to valueRole.dim, to make it that a single measure dimension is ultimately represented by plots.
Don't bind the valueRole.dim, to any of the discrete visual roles, to make the plots represent the sum of the measure dimensions.
See for more information on supported data types.
